docs.lead_paragraph: Takeover Bid for Unocal Is About Business, Says the Chairman of Its Chinese Suitor Fu Chengyu, chairman of Cnooc Ltd., says profits, not politics, are behind his company's $18.5 billion proposal to buy Unocal, China's most ambitious takeover bid. ''I have no talent for politics,'' he said, ''only business.'' [Page A1.] UnitedHealth to Buy PacifiCare for $8.14 Billion The UnitedHealth Group, the nation's second-largest health insurer, made a big push into the rapidly growing Medicare market by agreeing to buy PacifiCare Health Systems for $8.14 billion in cash and stock. [C1.] Boeing Sets Pay for Chief Executive The aircraft maker Boeing has agreed to pay its new chief executive, W. James McNerney Jr., total compensation that could top $53 million to wrest him away from 3M. [C1.] Charting the Cost of Malpractice Insurance In a study that may add fuel to the debate over the high price of medical malpractice insurance, the Center for Justice and Democracy found that net claims paid by 15 leading insurance companies stayed flat over the last five years, while net premiums surged 120 percent. [C1.] Food Companies Strike Back Against Obesity Suits Food and restaurant companies, fearing enormous judgments like those that hammered the tobacco industry, are fighting back against attempts to sue them for causing obesity or obesity-related health problems. [C1.] Microsoft and French Partner Detail Alliance The chief executives of Microsoft and France Télécom fleshed out the details of an alliance announced at the end of June. Steve Ballmer of Microsoft, near left, said two products under development were a mobile phone with Wi-Fi wireless capability, and a device with cellular, Wi-Fi and voice-over-Internet protocol technologies. Didier Lombard of France Télécom, far left, said another possibility raised was an updated Minitel, France's precursor to the Internet. [C3.] A Corporate Pitchman May Return to TV Chrysler is bringing back Lee A. Iacocca to do what he does best -- pitch cars in commercials. At least that is the plan. Chrysler executives said a deal was being negotiated with Mr. Iacocca, the company's 80-year-old retired chairman. The first of three commercials has already been shot. Advertising. [C1.] Actor Has Lead in Movie Download Venture A production company that is backed by Intel and counts Morgan Freeman, the actor, as an owner is forming a venture to sell movie downloads on the Internet. The new company, ClickStar, hopes to offer movies on the same day that they begin showing in theaters. [C6.] Utah Bank to Enter Texas With $1.7 Billion Deal Zions Bancorp, a Salt Lake City bank founded by the Mormon Church, has agreed to buy Amegy Bancorp for $1.7 billion to extend its eight-state, 400-branch network into Texas. Amegy investors will receive cash or stock valued at $23.32 a share, the companies said. Zions traces its roots to 1873, when the Mormon leader Brigham Young created the Zions Savings Bank and Trust Company. [C11.] Weather Roils Crude Oil Market Crude oil prices surged above $61 a barrel after a tropical storm curbed production in the Gulf of Mexico and forced the evacuation of offshore operations. Oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange reached $61.35 a barrel, then closed at $61.28, up $1.69. Market Place. [C3.] Stocks fell as oil prices caused investors to look past a report showing strong growth in the service sector. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 101.12 points, to 10,270.68. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 10.05 points, at 1,194.94, and the Nasdaq lost 10.10 points, to 2,068.65. [C11.] General Electric in Aircraft Financing Deal The CIT Group said it agreed to sell nearly $1 billion of corporate aircraft leases and loans to General Electric. [C17.] A.I.G. Executive to Oversee Reinsurance The American International Group, the insurer sued by the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, over suspected improper reinsurance accounting, appointed an executive to oversee its reinsurance relationships. [C3.] Scandal Ripples Beyond Volkswagen A rapidly expanding bribery and corruption scandal at Volkswagen threatens one of Germany's most prominent corporate executives and could harm Chancellor Gerhard Schröder. [C4.] Cellphones That Carry a Tune The cellphone has acquired several new features in recent years, from text messaging to video. Now cellphone makers and wireless operators are shifting their attention to music. Circuits. [C9.]

headline.main: Fast Food and Obesity in America

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman's column demonstrates how the redefining of medicine in America as a health care industry, where economics and consumerism are the central issue rather than health, undermines our efforts to find real solutions to the continual growth of degenerative illness.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Paul Krugman's column demonstrates how the redefining of medicine in America as a health care industry, where economics and consumerism are the central issue rather than health, undermines our efforts to find real solutions to the...

headline.main: The Food Industry Empire Strikes Back

docs.abstract: Article in series Obesity Inc: The Legal Battle focuses on fast food industry's lobbying effort to shield companies from court action; says bill that prohibit lawsuits by people claiming food company made them obese have become law in 20 states and are pending in another 11; National Restaurant Association and its 50 state organizations, which represent large chains like McDonald's and small independent businesses, has led campaign to curb lawsuits; maps; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Late-night comedians had a field day in the summer of 2002 when a lawsuit accusing McDonald's of making two teenage customers in New York fat and unhealthy was filed. But thousands of restaurant owners were not amused: Pelman v. McDonald's was the second time in a month that lawyers had tried to hold food companies responsible for America's obesity crisis.
docs.snippet: Food companies have had astounding success in their aggressive campaign to make it impossible for anyone to sue them for causing obesity.

headline.main: Fast Food and Obesity in America

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As the father of two young boys and as a family doctor who emphasizes prevention, I share Paul Krugman's concern about the rapid rise in childhood obesity and the power of large food companies to influence children's poor eating habits.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:      As the father of two young boys and as a family doctor who emphasizes prevention, I share Paul Krugman's concern about the rapid rise in childhood obesity and the power of large food companies to influence children's poor eating...

headline.main: Fast Food and Obesity in America

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman (''Girth of a Nation,'' column, July 4) correctly expresses the enormous threats, physical and financial, of epidemic obesity.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Paul Krugman (''Girth of a Nation,'' column, July 4) correctly expresses the enormous threats, physical and financial, of epidemic obesity.

headline.main: Fast Food and Obesity in America

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman, instead of suggesting that food companies are responsible for the food children eat and the health risks their indulgence may cause, should accept that people are responsible for their own eating habits.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Paul Krugman, instead of suggesting that food companies are responsible for the food children eat and the health risks their indulgence may cause, should accept that people are responsible for their own eating habits.

headline.main: Keep These Kids From Eating Veggies? Try.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE great grassy esplanade called the National Mall plays a multitude of roles in the life of the capital. Crowds gather there to witness inaugurals and celebrate patriotic holidays, and for decades demonstrators have assembled there to promote causes or to air grievances. In the course of a year you are likely to see almost anything or anyone on the Mall: kids flying kites or throwing Frisbees, bigger kids playing rugby, dogs chasing their tails. But a vegetable garden? A garden planned and tended by no less a figure than Alice Waters and her acolytes?
docs.snippet: Alice Waters, the queen of California cuisine, takes her theories on gardens, food and children to the Mall in Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Center for Consumer Freedom, an advocacy group financed by Coca-Cola, Wendy's and Tyson Foods, among others, has a Fourth of July message for you: worrying about the rapid rise in American obesity is unpatriotic. ''Far too few Americans,'' declares the center's Web site, ''remember that the Founding Fathers, authors of modern liberty, greatly enjoyed their food and drink. Now it seems that food liberty -- just one of the many important areas of personal choice fought for by the original American patriots -- is constantly under attack.''
docs.snippet: Obesity plays an important role in health care costs, but fat is both a fiscal issue and a partisan issue.

headline.main: Blockbuster Drugs Are So Last Century

docs.lead_paragraph: DRUG companies do an awful job of finding new medicines. They rely too much on billion-dollar blockbuster drugs that are both overmarketed and overprescribed. And they have been too slow to disclose side effects of popular medicines. Typical complaints from drug industry critics, right? Well, yes. Only this time they come from executives at Eli Lilly, the sixth-largest American drug maker and the company that invented Prozac.
docs.snippet: Eli Lilly sees its future in drugs that are aimed at smaller groups and can be developed more quickly and cheaply, possibly with fewer side effects.

headline.main: Were the Good Old Days That Good?

docs.lead_paragraph: TOM RATH, the protagonist in Sloan Wilson's 1955 novel, ''The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit,'' certainly had his share of troubles: the stressful conformity, the constant striving for success, the superficial suburban friendships, the war experiences he kept hidden from his wife. It all ate away at him. But Tom, like most Americans in the first three decades after World War II, took a rising standard of living for granted. When he needed more income to make ends meet, he simply landed a better-paying job. Indeed, at parties throughout suburbia, Mr. Wilson wrote, ''the public celebration of increases in salary was common.'' And Tom didn't fret about medical bills, job security or the quality of public schools for his three children.
docs.snippet: The American standard of living was climbing much faster in the 1950's compared with today's erratic gains.
